body.p: Atlassian Confluence is a content collaboration tool used to help teams collaborate and share knowledge efficiently. Based on my limited knowledge of Confluence I've identified these two ways in which you can write technical documentation in DITA and then make it available on the Confluence platform:

section.title: Publish DITA to Microsoft Word and import in Confluence
section.p: comes bundled with support to publish DITA content to Microsoft Word using the DITA to Word plugin: .

Once you publish the DITA project to Word, you can use the Import Word Document action from Confluence to import the Word document.During the import process you will be able to choose to split the document in multiple pages depending on the headings.

section.title: Publish DITA to HTML5 and import in Confluence
section.p: Although Confluence supports out of the box import only from Microsoft Word, there is a commercial file importer plugin for Confluence: . This plugin can import a number of file formats to Confluence, including Markdown and HTML.

The plugin contributes an import action which can be used to either import individual HTML or Markdown files or entire folders. The plugin might now want to import various file formats like CSS and JPEG so these types of files need to be manually deleted before the import.

section.title: Publish DITA to HTML5 and paste from Web Browser to Confluence
section.p: If you just want to update a couple of pages you can publish DITA to HTML, open the published HTML content in a web browser, select and copy the contents, then paste in a Confluence page. Confluence seems capable to convert the pasted HTML content to its own HTML-like format.
